base_layers.title: Zucchini and Corn Filling
directions: Toast corn in a skillet over high heat with oil and salt for about 5 minutes. Remove corn.
Cook onion in the skillet until it caramelizes (about 5 minutes). Leave onion in there.
Add garlic, cook another 1 or 2 minutes.
Add diced tomatoes, cook for 8-10 minutes.
Add zucchini, cook until it's tender.
Add corn back in.
Add black beans, Epazote; add salt, pepper, and other seasonings to taste. Cook for 3-4 more minutes.
base_layers.author: Noah <noah@noahveltman.com>

base_layers.title: Delengua (Beef Tongue)
base_layers.description: Entertaining? Wanna go exotic? Got a little bit of time? Makes in the neighborhood of 20 tacos.
ingredients: 1 small carrot, peeled and roughly chopped
directions: Combine tongue, onion, bay leaves, carrot, and garlic in a saucepan.
Add stock until mostly covered.
Bring to a boil over high heat, reduce to a simmer, cover with lid, and cook four to six hours until completely tender (depends on the size of the tongue).
Add water as necessary to keep the tongue mostly submerged.
Move tongue to a cutting board.
Strain stock and chuck the solids, keeping the liquid for later.
Peel the outer membrane off the tongue and discard. Chop tongue into 1/2-inch pieces.

When ready to serve, heat oil in a large non-stick skillet set over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add tongue and cook, stirring occasionally, until tongue is well browned on all sides, 5 to 8 minutes total.
notes: The first seven steps can be done well in advance. Should keep in fridge up to five days.
base_layers.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Swiss Chard
base_layers.description: This is actually a Rick Bayless recipe from his cookbook Mexican Everyday, but we've used it a fair amount on those days we feel like not eating meat but still want to have tacos.
ingredients: 1 bunch swiss or rainbow chard. Could also do spinach I guess. Probably not good with kale.
1/2 cup of chicken or vegetable broth
directions: Slice up the chard into small slices.
In a large skillet, heat the oil on medium-high. Cook the onions until soft, plus some garlic and red pepper flakes if you want.
Put the chard in the skillet, add the broth.
Cover the pan and reduce the heat to medium-low and cook until the greens are wilted and almost tender (about 5 minutes).
Uncover, bring heat back to medium high and cook until almost dry. Salt as necessary. Enjoy.
base_layers.author: Jacob Harris <jharris@nytimes.com>

base_layers.title: Soyrizo
ingredients: Soyrizo (The El Burrito branded 'SoyRizo' is by far the best vegan option out there)
directions: Throw some Soyrizo in a sauce pan with chopped potatoes and green peppers and brown for added bonus.
base_layers.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: @deezthugs' Smokey Turkey Tacos
base_layers.description:
These tacos have and will blow minds.

(Note:  I cannot separate the base_layer here from the seasoning, it is all integral)
ingredients: 2 Packages ground Turkey or Chicken (1.5 to 2 lbs) - not the lean stuff for Chrissake!
Several slices of cooked bacon, diced
2 Tbs Bacon Grease. That's right, Bacon Grease. (What you don't keep it? Might as well just quit now)
(The following dry ingredients can be increased depending on amount of meat)
1 tsp Chipotle powder (use as much as required)
directions: Combine all dry seasonings in bag, shake up and combine well with raw turkey meat. return to fridge for an hour or more.

Melt the Bacon Grease over medium heat, add Coconut oil and diced onion, cook down till onions are, well, you know, awesome. Add the smashed garlic. Add the bacon. Add the turkey meat and break it down into medium/small bits with a spatula or butter knife. After cooking for a few minutes and the meat has begun to brown, drizzle 2 of limes' juice onto the meat.
Cook well, adding optional chicken broth to shape the consistency as needed. (Generally not needed unless you accidentally buy low-fat meat. Shame on you.)

Finally, transfer amount for a meal to a frying pan, frying for a few minutes to create some crispy bits (This is the key step:)), adding lime juice as it cooks.  Spoon onto favorite tortillas add condiments and devour.
base_layers.author: David Dahl <ddahl@nulltxt.se>

base_layers.title: Slow-Cooked Salsa Verde Chicken
base_layers.description: Low-effort, delicious shredded chicken based off this recipe. To minimize prep time, just toss in a jar of storebought salsa verde.
ingredients: 1 tsp minced garlic or 1/4 tsp garlic powder
directions: Add chicken to slow cooker and season with garlic, oregano, cumin and salt. Pour salsa verde over everything, cover and cook for two hours on high.
Once that's ready, shred chicken. Give it another stir to cover everything in sauce, then serve.
base_layers.author: katiepark <katie.e.park@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Seasoned Lentils
base_layers.description: This is a quick and easy vegetarian substitute for ground beef that adds an interesting texture and a lot of similar flavor
directions: Cook lentils according to package directions (generally just boiling in water). Set aside.
In a skillet sauté onion and tomato in vegetable oil for a few minutes
Stir in seasoning mix, amount of water specified on mix packet and cooked lentils.
Follow directions on seasoning packet.
Enjoy!
base_layers.author: Todd Budnikas <toddb@missiondata.com>

base_layers.title: Red Cabbage Filling
directions: Mix all ingredients in large bowl
base_layers.author: Josh Williams <josh.williams@nytimes.com>

base_layers.title: Taco de rajas poblanas
ingredients: , queso Oaxaca or panela or fresco
directions:
Start with 1 or more produce-section bags of Poblano peppers,
it's handy if the bags are not totally full for a subsequent step.

Place the Poblano peppers over an open flame, typically directly
over a natural gas burner on a stove. Their skin will bubble and blister,
rotate and rearrange them with tongs until the burns, bubbles, and
blisters are evenly distributed around the chiles and you feel a tingle
in your upper sinuses. Put the singed peppers back in the produce bags,
then close the bags tightly to 'sweat' the chiles inside.

While the chiles are sweating, sautee some onion slices in a pan.
Optionally, add some pre-cooked whole kernels of corn when the onion is
almost done.

Take the chiles out of the bag. Their skin will be wilted and will come off
in your fingers. Peel the outer layer of the chiles off and discard. Once
the outer skin is removed, de-vein the rest and remove the seeds. Then
cut the flesh into thinninsh strips.

Add the chile strips (the 'rajas') back into the pan with the onion. Get it
all hot and finish cooking any bits of chile that remain raw after the
skin removal process. When it looks close to done, lower the cooking heat
to a minimum and add the cream and cheese(s) and warm them for about 5 minutes.
base_layers.author: Brian Mount <bvmount@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Pork Shoulder with Chile and Onions
base_layers.description: This is  my attempt to re-create my most favorite al pastor in Oakland -- the stuff they make at Tacos Sinaloa in Fruitvale. Saucy, packed with sauteed onions -- it's amazing stuff. This isn't a match, but it's damn fine, and close. I like it with roasted tomatillo salsa and crema  and a Dos Equis amber.
ingredients: Some number of pounds of pork shoulder. Get the good stuff; the pork will taste of its fat, and cheap pork fat tastes gross. A pound of pork shoulder makes dinner for 3-4 people, depending on just how many tacos each of you can put down.

ingredients.title: Per pound of pork:
ingredients: 1 medium onions (can do two large onions per three pounds pork). I like yellows, but I've done sweet onions and it's rad.

ingredients.title: chiles
ingredients: Let's pause here for a second, 'cause there are a  of great chiles you could use. I think this is best with dried red chiles, and ambrosial if those chiles were smoked. That means chipotles, anchos, or Oaxacenos. It's difficult to give quantities on these things. It comes down to taste, hey? If you don't cook with these things often, or don't like spicy foods, use Oaxacenos -- one or even a half of one per pound. If you like it hot, keep adding chipotles until your head explodes. I like spicy pork; I typically use two chiplotles per pound, depending on chili size. If you aren't big on smoked chiles, look at a dried New Mexico red, or use fresh-ground .

directions: Set the oven to 350 degrees. Put a Dutch Oven on the range and apply medium heat.
Chop up your pile of onions. Mince up the garlic. Heck -- get a beer. This is good beer-drinking-cooking. And the chiles! Chop them up too. That'll get you going.*
Oh yeah -- cut your pork shoulder into hunks of roughly equal size. I try to keep the hunks as big as possible. Coat it all over with salt.

So. Here's the basic idea: we're going to roast a pork shoulder. We don't want it to get dried out; we also don't want to add liquid to it. The moisture will come from the onions, which we also want to caramelize. What we're going to do is this: start with a base of cooked onions; start roasting the pork shoulder; add onions to keep it moist, but not too many or too fast so that they can get dry enough to caramelize. You can work the lid, here -- add it if things are drying out too quickly, remove if things are staying too wet.

Add a tablespoon or so of the oil of your choice to the Dutch Oven (I use bacon fat). Once it's hot, toss in 1/2-1/3 of your chopped onion. Cook the onion until it turns translucent; add about half the chopped chiles and garlic, stir well, then add the pork shoulder. Start them fat-side down, and try to get the fat in contact with the dutch oven.
Pop the whole works in the oven, uncovered (to start). Grab your beer, and maybe a book. Time to do some structured waiting.

Every thirty minutes or so, check the pork shoulder. Check the stuff in the bottom of the pan; as it starts to dry out, throw in more onions and stir it all around. You can flip the hunks over after a while -- use tongs.

The pork shoulder is done when it is tender but not soft. You should be able to separate the hunks with a pair of forks, but you should not be able to cut it with a fork. Honestly, I like mine a touch on the chewy side -- well roasted and cooked through but not actually falling apart. (Try this: slice off a little hunk of pork. Is it delicious? Just a little chew? It's done! If it's tough, keep going.) For a three pound pork shoulder in my oven, this takes about two hours.
When the pork shoulder is done, pull the hunks out of the pot with tongs, transferring them to a cutting board. Transfer the Dutch Oven back to the range and set medium heat.
Chop the pork hunks into bits.

Toss whatever onion and chile and garlic you have left into the Dutch Oven to cook in the rendered fat and onion goop. If things are stuck or cooked to the pan, pour in a bit of your beer to loosen it. Do you like flavors other than what's already there? Oregano or cumin? This is where I'd add those, m'self, but I don't usually want 'em.
Once the onion in the pot is tender, toss the pork back in and stir liberally.

Hey, you're done! It's ready to go in tacos! I love this as a simple taco: hot corn tortillas, this stuff, roasted tomatillo salsa, a little crema, but it would win your heart with seared corn and epazote and maybe some cotija. You should eat as you like!
notes: Have you handled very hot peppers before? No? Okay, listen, this is really important: hot chiles will get oil on your fingers, and it will burn any sensitive body parts you touch. That oil is very difficult to scrub off, so just washing your hands isn't enough. Dried chiles are much safer to work than fresh or freshly roasted chiles, but you can still have an awfully rough evening of pouring salene solution in your eyes if you aren't careful. When in doubt: nitrile gloves.
base_layers.author: Ross Donaldson <gastove@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Puerco Pibil
base_layers.description: A delicious, slow roasted Pork dish from the Yucatan. Can be served over rice or used as a base layer in tacos!
ingredients: 2 chopped Habenero Chiles, stems and seeds removed.
directions: Grind the spices in a coffee grinder. Don't use your usual coffee grinder. Use a grinder that you use specifically for spices only.
Add the chiles, oj, vinegar, salt, lemon juice, tequila, and spice mix to a blender and blend well.
Cut the pork into 2 inch cubes and place in a large zip lock bag.
Preheat oven to 325 degrees (if you haven't yet).
Pour the blended mixture into the bag and seal. Be sure to coat all of the meat with the mixture.
Line a 9 x 13 inch pan with Banana leaves.
Pour entire contents of the zip lock bag into the pan.
Cover with more Banana leaves.
Cover entire pan tightly with aluminum foil.
Put the pan in the oven and relax for the next 4 hours.
Enojoy!

base_layers.author: Nathan Arnold <nathan@shorepound.net>

base_layers.title: Braised Pork Belly
base_layers.description:
Pork belly can be intimidating, but the reward is melt-in-your-mouth deliciousness! The crispy pork belly, creamy avocado, and crunchy onions are a perfect blend of textures in this taco. DO try this at home :)

Pork belly recipe adapted from Mario Batali
directions: Preheat oven to 350 F
Combine rub ingredients
Without slicing the pork belly the whole way through, score the fat of the pork belly in a 1-inch grid pattern
Massage the rub into pork belly
Chop vegetables into 1/2 inch pieces
Heat a large dutch oven over medium high-heat with a few tablespoons of olive oil
Sear the pork, fat side down, until golden brown and crispy
Flip pork and add the carrots, celery, red onion, fennel, fennel seeds, beer and season with salt
Bring to a boil
Transfer meat to the preheated oven and cook, uncovered, for 1.5 to 2 hours
Once the pork belly has finished cooking, slice into 1/4 inch thick slabs - use 2 slices per taco, or more if desired
Add green tomatillo salsa, fresh avocado, and onions and cilantro to garnish
Best in corn tortillas, but flour or wheat tortillas are also acceptable
base_layers.author: Sarah Fulgham <safulgham@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Pepper Tempeh
ingredients: Ample amounts of coarsely ground black pepper to taste
directions: Cut tempeh into thin slices
Combine olive oil, vinegar, soy sauce, garlic powder and water in a bowl and marinate the Tempeh for 10-30 minutes.
Add the tempeh and marinade to a skillet and saute over medium heat until liquid evaporates.
Add a bit more water and continue to cook for about 2 minutes.
base_layers.author: Geoffrey Hing <geoff@terrorware.com>

base_layers.title: Pan-seared salmon
directions: Cut the salmon into 1x1 inch cubes (or any size that you think is a good mouthful).
Pat the cubes dry and season with salt and pepper.
Heat about a tablespoon of butter/ghee/vegetable oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Add the salmon and turn heat to medium-low.
Fry the salmon until cooked through, about 4 minutes depending on the size.
base_layers.author: Madeleine Schönemann <madeleine.schonemann@tretton37.com>

base_layers.title: Overly Seasoned Ground Beef
base_layers.description:
I enjoy tripling (or more) the generic store bought taco seasoning when rendering my ground beef.

I've found that while with most cooking, you can in fact over season pretty easily, that's not the case with taco ground beef.

I will aggressively season the beef, even adding additional cumin and garlic.

This basically seasons the entire taco, so you can spend less time prepping all of the toppings.
base_layers.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Slow Cooked No-Bean Chili
base_layers.description: Super delicious and spicy no-bean chili made from scratch.
directions: Remove the stems and the seeds from the dried peppers. Cover them with water in a small pot and boil for 15 minutes.
Mix the peppers with the water until it transforms into a sort of chili sauce.
Finely chop the garlic and jalapeños.

directions.title: Cut the beef in 2 cm cubes and sear them on high temperature in oil together with the garlic.
directions: Protip: You'll get much better result if you don't sear all the beef at once.
Sprinkle the spice mix over the beef.
Lower the temperature and add the chili sauce we made in the beginning.
Add enough beer that it covers everything and throw in the bouillon cube.

directions.title: Cover the cooking pot and let it simmer a couple of hours until the meat is all stringy and nice.
directions: Protip: Crack a bottle of beer, sit back and relax as this will take a while.
Protip: Lower temperature → longer cooking time → better result.
Remove the cover and reduce the liquid until the texture is perfect™.

directions.title: Balance up the flavors with salt, black pepper and brown sugar.
directions: Protip: A couple of dashes of soy sauce is nice if you're looking for a darker color.

base_layers.author: Henric Englund <hnrcnglnd@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Moroccan Lamb
base_layers.description: A Differently Spiced Meat Than Your Usual Taco

ingredients.title: 20 g Ras al Hanout spice. My mix contains:

ingredients: 10 g fresh lemon zest or 10 g finely ground Black Lemon Omani (Moroccoan dried preserved lemon)
directions: Mix together and brown.
base_layers.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

base_layers.title: Marinated Portobello Mushroom
base_layers.description: Sometimes you're throwing a taco party and you need a vegetarian option. Sometimes you just don't feel like eating meat.
directions: Since a proper taco is never overstuffed, one decent-sized portobello should be enough for three servings. Multiply accordingly, and drop your mushrooms into a big Ziploc bag with enough  to cover. Let everything sit in your fridge for a couple of hours.

Remove, season with just a touch of salt and cracked black pepper, then lay onto a grill (or a grill pan on your stovetop) over medium to medium-high heat for a few minutes on each side. Cut into thick slices, and you'll have a nice, earthy taco base.
base_layers.author: Ryan Pitts <ryan.a.pitts@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Insane Garlic Ground Turkey
base_layers.description:
While not particularly fancy, the insane garlic ground turkey is a crowd pleaser.

Total cooking time: 30-40 minutes
ingredients: 2 pounds of ground turkey (preferably thigh meat)
More garlic than you can imagine (4-5 cloves)
directions: Chop several onions into slices.
In a large pan heat olive oil in a saucepan over high heat
Cook onions on high heat until they are almost caramelized. (10 minutes)
Reduce heat to medium.
Add ground turkey making sure to stir meat to ensure adequate turkey / onion mixture.
Cover and let turkey cook for 8 minutes.
Mix taco seasoning using one cup of water for each packet of seasoning
Add several cloves or garlic to pan.  When in doubt with garlic always err on the side of too much.
Cook uncovered until taco seasoning is reduced.
Warn guests of impending garlic.
base_layers.author: Tim O'Brien <tobrien@discursive.com>

base_layers.title: Ground Beef (Traditional; US)
base_layers.description: The tranditional base for an American taco is ground beef, browsed in a skillet and seasoned.
directions: Heat a skillet on the stovetop.

Brown the ground beef for 8-10 minutes, or until it is thoroughly cooked, stirring frequently to avoid sticking or burning. (If you're not using a non-stick pan, which is preferred, use 1T oil to keep things loose.)
Stir in seasonings.
base_layers.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

base_layers.title: Garlic Black Beans
directions: Heat a tablespoon of olive oil in a saucepan over medium heat.
When olive oil starts to shimmer, add the garlic and let it simmer for about 10 seconds.
Add cumin and pepper (if wanted) and simmer for another 10 seconds.
Pour in the entire can of beans, don't drain or rinse them.

Simmer for about 15 minutes or until the bean broth has thickened to your liking. If the beans will be the main ingredient of your tacos, cook until the beans are just about totally dry. If you're using them in a mixture (like the  ), let the broth stay a little bit runny.
Add a squeeze or two of lemon juice if you like.
base_layers.author: Marie Mosley <mariemosley@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Fat-Poached Carnitas
ingredients: 3 pounds of boneless pork shoulder or uncured picnic ham (see note for how to select).
0.25 to 0.50 cups of liquified fat (oil, lard or duck fat is acceptable)
1 lemon, sliced into thin circles and those are quartered
directions: Heat oven to 250 degrees.
Cube pork shoulder in roughly 3-inch chunks.
Salt and pepper the cubes aggressively.
Stuff cubes tightly (very tightly) into the smallest, deepest baking dish available.
Stuff garlic and lemon between the cubes.
Pour fat over cubes to just cover.
Bake in oven for 5 hours.
Remove dish from oven.
Cover a sheet pan with foil.
With slotted spoon, remove the pork to the sheet pan and spread out in a single layer.
Turn on broiler.
Broil pork in sheet pan until it is somewhat blackened and crispy, probably 4-6 minutes. YMMV because broilers are ridiculous.
Remove from oven and tease with fork.
notes: A nice thick fat cap on the top of the pork is preferable.
Ask your butcher to remove any bones.
Do not use cured meat.
base_layers.author: Jeremy Bowers <jeremyjbowers@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Crock Pot Pulled Pork
base_layers.description:
This is the base of my very favorite tacos. Added bonus is by cooking these all day in a slow cooker, your house smells amazing.

Note: Unless you're cooking for a dozen people, you're going to end up with a lot of leftover pork, but that's about the best problem you can possibly have.

GET GOING EARLY–in a perfect world, you're gonna give this thing at least eight hours on low.
directions: Chop up your onion or shallot into small bits–you don't want big loops of onion, dice it.
Rub your hunk of pork generously with chili powder, oregano, pepper, salt, and a pinch or two of cumin. I tend to try and have a very light crust of this stuff on the outside of the pork.

Toss the hunk of pork, the onions, and the green chilis into the crock pot, set that sucker to LOW, and let it slow cook. I try to get mine in by 9am so I can eat around 6pm. If you're pressed for time, you can do this in about four hours on high, but the deliciousness factor is lowered.

Once the time is up, either shred the thing up in the crock pot or, if you can actually get it out without it falling apart, get it into a bowl and shred from there. That way, you're getting it out of what ends up being a GIGANTIC AMOUNT of juices. But again: oh no, your pork ended up sitting in a big vat of juice–we all weep for you.
base_layers.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Crock Pot (Fake) Al Pastor
base_layers.description: This isn't authentic al pastor (the real preparation is very similar to shawarma) but it's got the same flavors, and is super easy and crazy delicious.
ingredients: 1 medium bone-in pork shoulder (Boston butt), skin removed
2/3 of a pineapple, peeled, cored, and roughly chopped
Fish sauce to taste (a few tablespoons)
Kekap manis (Indonesian sweet soy sauce, available at most Asian supermarkets) to taste. Feel free to substitute regular soy sauce. About 1/4 cup
One 14.5 oz can tomatoes, preferably fire roasted
directions: Coat the shoulder generously with salt, and brown it well on all sides in a hot pan.
Puree the peppers, adobo, pineapple, fish sauce, kekap manis, tomatoes, and cumin in a food processor or blender to a smooth puree. Taste and adjust seasoning.
Pour half of the puree into a crock pot, and add the browned pork.
Add a little liquid to the pan the pork cooked in (water, stock, beer, whatever's on hand) and scrape up all the good brown bits. Pour into the crock pot.
Add the rest of the puree to the crock pot, then stick the whole thing in the fridge for at least an hour, or overnight.
Cook the pork on the lowest setting for 10-12 hours, until it pulls apart very easily.
Turn the crock pot to off, and leave the pork in the pot to cool for 30 minutes.

Remove the pork to a platter or cookie sheet, and spoon off as much fat as possible from the top of the remaining liquid. Wick the last of the fat off with paper towels. If making  reserve 2 tablespoons of the fat.
Remove the bones and chunks of fat from the pork, and add it back to the liquid in the crockpot. Shred with two forks, and rewarm if necessary.
base_layers.author: bchartoff <bchartoff@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Corn and Black Beans
base_layers.description:
Delicious hot as the main base_layer or as a supplement to others.

This is a fork of the Zuccini and Corn Filling because I'm not a Zuccini fan. I also tweaked the spices.
ingredients: Fresh corn kernels, cut off the cob.
directions: Toast corn in a skillet over high heat with oil and salt for about 5 minutes, or until browned. Remove corn.
Cook onion in the skillet until it caramelizes (about 5 minutes). Leave onion in there.
Add corn back in.
Add black beans.
Toss in a pinch of salt, a healthy couple shakes of chili powder, and a small pinch of cumin.
Cook together for another 5 minute or so.
base_layers.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Chorizo
base_layers.description:
Perfect, lightly seasoned taco meat.

_Adapted from Aredridel's Lightly Seasoned Beef_
ingredients: 4 g salt if wine is unsalted
directions: Heat oil in the pan.
Add in onions, stirring occasionally until onions become translucent.
Toss in the garlic, and the chorizo on top of that.
Add the cumin. Brown the chorizo.
Use the splash of wine to loosen anything stuck to the pan.
base_layers.author: Arelia <arelia.jones@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Chopped Steak
base_layers.description: I like all kinds of steak tacos, but lately have been into cubed up steak tacos that are allowed to marinate a little bit in some salsa verde and other spices. Here's the ones I made tonight.
ingredients: 1lb rib eye steak, cubed into ~1" cubes
Salsa verde, your choice, about 2-3 Tbs
Pinch or two of mexican oregano
A few healthy sprinkles of chili powder
directions: Cube up your steak, mix everything together, cover and let sit for a half hour or so.
When everything else is ready to go, pan-fry (or, skewer and grill if you're feeling ambitious), until cooked to your chosen meat level.
base_layers.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Chopped Pork
base_layers.description: This is a quick and easy way to prep and cook your pork for tacos.
ingredients: pork chops, boneless, don't go too crazy thick, around 1-2" tops.
directions: Do you see where this is going? Cut up your chops unevenly with the scissors. Go for an average of chopped bits around 1" in size or so, but variation is good, especially little bits. Those little bits are going to turn into crispy bits of goodness. When you..
Prior to the pan-tossing, you should spice up your pork with a good rub or marinade. If you're looking, I recommend the .
Toss all this into a high-heat pan (cast iron, if you've got it) and fry it up so that it chars up real nice. The little bits will turn into little charred chunks--this is a feature, not a bug.
base_layers.author: sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Chipotle Shrimp
directions: In a bowl, add the shrimp and Chipotle Rub and stir to coat well.
Heat a large non-stick skillet over medium-high heat and add the butter.
When butter has melted, add the shrimp to the skillet. Cook for 1-2 minutes, and flip shrimp. Cook for 1-2 more minutes, or just until shrimp are pink. Remove shrimp from skillet.
base_layers.author: Erin Morrissey <erinmorrissey@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Carnitas
base_layers.description: This recipe calls for both slow cooking the roast as well as frying before serving.
directions: Place a pork shoulder roast in a crock pot, cover roast completely with water.
Sprinkle onion & garlic powder into crock pot.
Cook for 6 to 8 hours on high, or 8 to 10 hours on low.
If frying at a later time, refrigerate roast with some of the cooking water.
When ready to make tacos, shred the meat.
Chop up as much jalapenos and green onions as desired.
In a large frying pan add some oil. When the oil is hot but not burning add the meat and fry.
Add some of the cooking water as needed to fry pan to keep the meat moist.
In the last 5 or so minutes of cooking the meat, add the jalapenos and onions to meat.
Meat should come out crispy but still moist
Serve on tortillas (preferably soft corn tortillas) with choice of condiments (salsa, cheese, onions, etc)
base_layers.author: supersloth <joshua.rivera@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Roasted Butternut Squash
base_layers.description: The great thing about roasting butternut squash is that you just throw the whole squash into the oven, forget about it for about an hour, and the cooking is all self-contained - no prep (no need to chop up an uncooked gourd), no other ingredients and no messy dishes afterward.
directions: Roast a whole butternut squash in the oven at 400 degrees for 30 minutes to an hour until it is nice and soft.

Cut open the squash, scoop out the seeds and discard the peel. Cut into bite-sized pieces and the squash is ready to go. No seasoning is necessary, but the sweet buttery flavor of the squash is pretty tasty with chili powder.
base_layers.author: Cassie McDaniel <cassie@mozillafoundation.org>

base_layers.title: Bulgar Black Bean Filling
base_layers.description: This is a quick and easy vegetarian substitute for a ground beef-like texture without using a soy substitute.
ingredients: 1/3 cup cooked black beans (or canned), rinsed and strained.
directions: Mix bulgar and black beans together. For better texture, slightly mash the black beans.
Add your choice of seasonings to taste and serve.
base_layers.author: Javaun Moradi <jmoradi@npr.org>

base_layers.title: Boiled Ground Beef
base_layers.description:
Boiling ground beef is a great way to to preserve flavor and delicious juiciness. This process requires a bit more time, but it's totally worth it.

(Credit belongs to my wife, Jamie. See the full recipe here.)
ingredients: enough water to completely cover the meat
directions: Place all ingredients in a large pan over high heat. Bring to boil. Turn down to medium/medium low heat and simmer for 1 hour. Use a potato masher to break apart the meat.

Strain away any leftover liquid. If you are making this ahead of time you can place the leftover liquid in the fridge to harden the grease. Spoon off any hardened grease and add a little liquid back to the meat if you are reheating it.
base_layers.author: Alex P. Gates <alex@whatcheer.com>

base_layers.title: Better Than Powder Ground Beef
base_layers.description: Did you grow up on Old El Paso ground beef taco seasonings? I'm sorry.  So did I.  They're terrible, right?  Here's something better.
directions: Brown a pound of ground beef, seasoning liberally with ground cumin, salt, pepper. Add tabasco/other hot sauce if you like.
When beef is browned, add a small jar of salsa (any kind!  i like corn/black bean tomato salsa), and simmer for 5-10 minutes.
Enjoy.  Serve with crispy taco shells for nostalgia.
base_layers.author: Jon Janego <jonjanego@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Bell-pepper
directions: A bell-pepper is typically cut up and then tossed into a skillet or something else to heat it. Olive oil is nice. They can be grilled as well.
base_layers.author: nick11robers <nick.roberts.127.0.0.1@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: North Carolina Battered Catfish
base_layers.description: Do it right and stick your arm down a catfish hole in the muddy waters of a north carolina pond, take that sucker home at serve it up to your friends and family on some corn tortilas
directions: Preheat a deep-fryer to 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
In a large bowl, add the flour, cornmeal, baking powder, salt and cayenne and whisk to combine. Whisk in the beer, being sure to remove any lumps.

Cut the catfish fillets in half lengthwise to make 2 strips. If desired, cut into bite-sized pieces. In a small bowl add the salt, pepper and granulated garlic. Season the fillets with the salt mixture.

Dip each strip in the beer batter and add to the fryer, a few at a time, moving them around so they don't stick. Fry until brown and crispy, about 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from the fryer to a serving platter. Repeat with the remaining fillets and season the fish with lemon juice. Cut them up into taco size portions and show your friends how amazing your catch tastes.
base_layers.author: cole <mcg42387@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Basic Shredded Chicken
base_layers.description: This recipe creates enough shredded chicken for 2 to 3 meals. It's a savory, universal base; once cooked, you can supplement with any number of spices or treatments to make tacos, taquitos, soups, enchiladas ... even Italian or Indian applications if you like.
directions: Salt the chicken breasts (be reasonably generous here), then crack some black pepper over each. In your crockpot, mix garlic powder, chili powder, cumin and oregano into the broth. Place chicken in crockpot, then cook on low for 8 hours.
When the chicken is done, attack each piece with two forks to shred. Do this on a Sunday and you'll have an easy time putting together meals throughout the week.

I often give this a quick simmer with a bit of water and  for taco filling. Or throw it into tortilla soup. Or make some sweet . Or just add some barbecue sauce to a handful of chicken, and toss it onto a soft roll for a quick sandwich. Man  live on tacos alone, but one doesn't have to.
base_layers.author: Ryan Pitts <ryan.a.pitts@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Baked Tilapia
base_layers.description: Oven fried fish for when you think you want to pretend you're eating healthier.
ingredients: 1 pound mild fish (I usually use tilapia)
directions: Preheat oven to 400 degrees.
Mix dry ingredients in a bowl to make the coating for the fish.
Cut fish into slices or chunks, as your taste desires.
Drizzle olive oil over cut fish, and dip fish into breading.
Bake for 8ish minutes and finish, if you can, under the broiler.
base_layers.author: katemyers <kate.myers@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Baja Beer Battered Fish
base_layers.description: This is the beer battered fish for Baja fish tacos.
ingredients: 1 tsp chili powder (paprika, salt, garlic salt)
1 lb. cod fillet, grouper, or similar white fish, the fresher the better
directions: Batter
Fish
base_layers.author: Kumar McMillan <kumar.mcmillan@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Asian Style Tofu or Pork Marinade
directions: Mix with sliced tofu or pork, marinate for 30 minutes and quickly sauté.
base_layers.author: Karthik Ram <karthik.ram@gmail.com>

base_layers.title: Lightly Seasoned Beef
base_layers.description: Perfect, lightly seasoned taco meat.
ingredients: 500 g ground beef or chopped steak
4 g salt if wine is unsalted
directions: Heat oil in the pan.
Toss in the garlic, and the beef on top of that.
Add the cumin. Brown the beef.
Use the splash of wine to loosen anything stuck to the pan.
base_layers.author: Aria Stewart <aredridel@nbtsc.org>

condiments.title: Yogurt
condiments.description: Plain Balkan or Greek type yogurts add flavour and moisture. May be used as an alternative to sour cream. While sweet and fruit flavoured yogurts are not recommended, speciality yogurt dips such as jalapeno provide delicious variation.
condiments.author: tamahoc <tamahoc@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Vindaloo Sauce
condiments.description: Vindaloo is an Indian curry sauce that is popular in the Goa region of India. Vindaloo sauce can be prepared or store bought.
condiments.author: nick11robers <nick.roberts.127.0.0.1@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Above Average Tomato Sauce
ingredients: 1 24oz jar or can of crushed tomatos or tomato puree
condiments.author: Geoff Hing <geoffhing@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Spicy Mayo
directions: Mix mayonnaise and gochujang together well. Let sit for 20 minutes so flavors can combine.
notes: Gochujang paste can be found at asian markets.
condiments.author: Erin Morrissey <erinmorrissey@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Sour Cream
condiments.description: Cool and tart, sour cream is an almost-essential part of the traditional American taco, and many others as well.
condiments.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

condiments.title: Simple Salsa Verde
condiments.description: I got this base recipe from a vegan friend. If you can't find one of these peppers, swap in another one!
ingredients: Juice of 1 or 2 fresh-squeezed limes (to taste)
Pinch or two kosher salt (to taste)
directions: You're in charge of the heat here. For a milder salsa, remove all the ribs and seeds inside the peppers. For medium, leave in a few ribs, and for hot, go nuts. Rough chop the peppers and tomatillos, then throw into a blender or food processor with salt and lime juice. Pulse to desired consistency.
As with most salsas, this will taste better if you let it sit in the fridge for a few hours before eating. It's great on chips or drizzled over steak or pork tacos.
condiments.author: Ryan Pitts <ryan.a.pitts@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Salsa Sauce
condiments.description: From What's Cookin' Cookbook: A Recipe Collection from the Schlaback Family
directions: Mix and bring to a boil.
Cook down 1 1/2 hours.
Cold pack for 20 minutes.
condiments.author: Katherine Michel <kthrnmichel@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Salsa de Aguacate
condiments.description: This is the traditional green sauce served from a Mexican taco cart. Very popular with Tacos al Pastór or Tacos de Canasta, it is a creamy, green sauce. It has avacado, but it by no means a guacamole. Usually available with other taco cart staples such as: sliced radishes, spicy salsa roja, fresh cilantro, and fresh limes.
ingredients: 1/2 cup crema (Mexican sour cream, thinner and sweeter than standard sour cream)
directions: Cook the tomatillos and peppers in a pot with water until soft. Drain the water out and let cool.

Put tomatillos, peppers, salt, lime-juice, crema, and avacado (shelled and pitted) in blender. With lid on, blend until completely mixed and liquid consistency. Salsa should be the consistency of crema, liquid, yet slightly viscous.
Pour over your tacos liberally. Refrigerate between uses.
condiments.author: Paul C Pederson <ppederson@esri.com>

condiments.title: Roasted Tomatillo and Mushroom Sauce
condiments.description: A friend gave me this recipe a while back, but I can't remember who it was. Sorry, friend.
directions: Remove husks from tomatillos and rinse them. Place them whole on your oven's broiler rack. Broil and turn them until they're browned on all sides.
Boil the water. Drop in the dried chiles and bring the water down to a simmer. Keep them in until they are soft.
Slice the shiitakes and cook them in a pan with the olive oil until they're tender.
Take the chiles and tomatillos (once they're cooled off) and blend them in a food processor until they make a nice puree.

Put the blended tomatillo-chile mixture in a saucepan and bring it to a boil. Add the cooked mushrooms and bring it back to a boil. Then bring the heat down until the mixture is simmering. Cook for about 10 minutes. Add salt to taste.
condiments.author: Chris Cieslak <chris@electropuf.com>

condiments.title: Pineapple Lime Crema
directions: Whisk ingredients together in small bowl.
Place in refrigerator until ready to use.
condiments.author: Lulu <lilulu004@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Asian Pickled Vegetables
directions: Whisk ingredients in bowl.
Toss in sliced vegetables.
Mix, cover and chill in fridge for at least 30 minutes before using.
condiments.author: Karthik Ram <karthik.ram@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Pickled Red Onions Variation
condiments.description: Pickled onions are a favorite in the Von Doom house, too. @littlewhirl played around with a similar starting point and we use this brine instead:
ingredients: 1 T Sugar (I usually use coconut palm sugar because I'm a hippie I guess)
directions: Slice 1 red onion on a mandolin (WORTH IT).
In a bowl melt the sugar and salt with some warm/hot water.
Add vinegar and 1c of filtered water.
Add in onion, top off w/ water so that the onion is just covered.
VERY IMPORTANT: Let sit at room temp for at least an hour. Trust me.
notes: The apple cider vinegar is a tangier but also more subtle, keeping more of the onion flavor there. And using a partial salt water brine lets it work nice for quick pickles, but also for slightly longer engagements. Leading to the most important aspect.

notes.title: PICKLE ALL THE THINGS
notes: Seriously. All the things. Pickle your fridge. Pickle your waffles. Make. Lots. Of. Pickles.
— red or green work. You only need an hour or so (like onions)
— seriously GTFO these are good. Add dill for a twist. Add parboiled carrots if you want to cut the spice
— because greenbeans are goddam delicious
__Toy cars — kid with an attitude? Pickle their favorite toy car. Let's see them try to cop a tude when their matchbox cars are soggy and briney
— personal favorite. Pickles in an hour, super delicious
— baby corn is gross, but if you pickle it you can make jokes about how big all the other things you pickled are

condiments.author: CJ R <cj@null.computer>

condiments.title: Pickled Red Onions
condiments.description: My wife made this recipe up, after eating something similar, but if you are making brisket tacos, it is the most wonderful accessory.
directions: Chop the red onions into rings and put them into a container of vinegar. Add the sugar and store the mixture in your refrigerator to marinate and pickle, the longer the better.
Pick out the rings and place them on your brisket taco. Eat.
condiments.author: Jeff Larson <thejefflarson@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Pickled Jalapeños
directions: Bring vinegar, water, sugar, salt, oregano, garlic, and red pepper to a boil in a saucepan
Stir in sliced jalapeños, then remove from heat
Cover saucepan and allow it to sit for 15-20 minutes
Use tongs to put the jalapeños into a jar, then pour in the rest of the mixture until the jar is full
Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes (preferably overnight)
condiments.author: Nathaniel Brown <ngbrown11@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Onions and Cilantro
ingredients: Bunch of cilantro, long bottom stems removed (stems between leaves are fine).
directions: Dice white onion into 0.50 inch dice.
Roughly chop cilantro.
Add onion and cilantro to a bowl with the lime juice and mix thoroughly.
Store in an airtight container for up to a week.
condiments.author: jeremyjbowers <jeremyjbowers@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Mango Avocado Salsa
condiments.description: Goes great on soft shell chicken tacos with cheese (or deep-friend wantons with scallops)!
ingredients: Garlic cloves (leave it up to your buds)
directions: Chop avocado and mango into bowl.
Squeeze the lime and half the orange in, add honey.
Add garlic (chopped or pressed) and pepper to taste.
Stir and enjoy!
condiments.author: Shane Shifflett <shifflett.shane@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Mango Lime Salsa
condiments.description: This fresh mango salsa is sweet, tangy, and simple. It pairs exceedingly well with Garlic Lime Sauce for delicious fish tacos. The recipe is a simplified version of the mango salsa on Love and Oil.
directions: Combine in a bowl.
Stir and serve.
condiments.author: Javaun Moradi <jmoradi@npr.org>

condiments.title: Mango Avocado Pico de Gallo
condiments.description: Excellent topping for fish or chicken tacos, or served just with chips.
ingredients: 1 c. small cubes of mango (about 1 medium to large RIPE mango - not too mushy, though)
1/2-1 large jalapeno pepper (1/2 without seeds will give you a nice, mild-medium heat - add from there)
1/4 of a medium red onion, finely chopped
Kosher or sea salt to taste
Dash of chipotle pepper flakes or chipotle tabasco sauce if smoke is your thing
directions: Combine ingredients.
Best served immediately, but will keep for a day.
condiments.author: harknessa <a.j.harkness@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Lime
directions: Cut a lime into quarters or eights and squeeze juice onto any taco.
condiments.author: Sean Fitzpatrick <sffitzpatrick@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Homemade Kimchi
condiments.description: Kimchi will take your taco in a decidedly unrestrained asian direction, but comfort zones were made to be broken. It takes some time to make, as fermentation needs to take place. It also may take some time to acquire a taste for it, but it's worth the effort.
ingredients: 8oz daikon radish, cut into matchstick-size strips.
directions: Split the cabbage in half lengthwise, then crosswise into 2-inch pieces; discard the root. Put the cabbage into a large bowl with the salt and toss until the salt is evenly distributed. Add cold water to cover, making sure the cabbage is submerged. Cover with saran wrap and let it sit at room tempurature anywhere form 12-24 hours.
Drain the cabbage and rinse in cold water. Gently squeeze to get as much liquid out as you cam, and set the cabbage aside in a smaller bowl.
Add the remaining ingredients to the large bowl and mix it all up. Add the cabbage and toss until the cabbage is thoroughly covered.
Pack it all into a 2 quart glass jar and close it up. Make sure you get a tight seal.
Stick the jar in a dark place for about 24 hours. Open the lid to let out the gasses that have been wanting to get out, then close it up again and put it in the fridge.
Wait two more days, and voila, you have kimchi. Some people sya that it's best to wait at least a week before eating; it will last about a month.
notes: Lots of other vegetables can be added; play around with it.
Thanks to Momofuku, we know that puréeing kimchi takes a lot of the sweater smell out of it, and creates a smoother and rounder flavor, and is fantastic for squeezing onto tacos.
condiments.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

condiments.title: Guacamole (Simple)
condiments.description: If you're not in the mood to be fussy, this could be considered a minimum-viable guacamole recipe.
ingredients: 2-4 limes, depending on juiciness, delivering 2-4T of lime juice
1 diced tomato (seeded if it's a big one)
hot sauce (to taste; Frank's Red Hot is a standard, but go with what you like)
directions: Scoop the avocado meat into a bowl and mash them with a fork. Leave it a bit lumpy as we will do more stirring in a bit and we don't want to over-work them.
Add the chopped tomato.
Add the lime juice; hold some back for later adjustment).
Add ½t salt.
Add 2T hot sauce.
Stir with the fork again.
Taste.
Adjust salt/lime/hot sauce as desired.
notes: This recipe will support one average-size bag of chips, so adjust quantities based on expectations.
condiments.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

condiments.title: Guacamole Boris Karloff
condiments.description: From the ubiquitous newspaper clipping, it's Karloff's recipe with sherry.
directions: Peel and mash avocados.
Add onion, tomato and chiles, then stir in lemon juice, sherry and seasonings to taste, blending well.
Serve as a dip for tortilla pieces or corn chips or as a canape spread.
Makes 10 to 12 appetizer servings.
condiments.author: CJ R <cj@null.computer>

condiments.title: Guacamole
condiments.description:
This is pretty canonical stuff right here.

Thanks to The Awl for limited inspiration regarding the limey and drinky parts.
ingredients: a clove or two of chopped garlic
some chopped white or yellow onion
dry cayenne or red chile pepper powder
a jalapeño, if that's your thing
directions: Look, here's how this works: First, you squeeze the lime juice into your nice little ceramic bowl. Then you add the garlic, onion, spices, peppers if you're heating it up, and then .

Seriously, walk away for a minute. Crack open a nice Negra Modelo and use a wedge of the other half of the lime in it. Back in your bowl, let the strong stuff marinate in that lime juice for a few minutes. It's cooking.

OK, now that you're back, mix in the rest of the non-avocado ingredients. If you have a pestle, now's it's time to shine. If not, use a small wooden spoon, or failing all else, a fork, you miserable lout.
Mash up everything but the avocado. Get it pasty if you can. Squish it all up.
Now you can add your avocado or two, dude. I usually go with about 1.5 avos to condiment tacos or taco-like structures for four humans of varying sizes.
Just in case no one ever taught you how to deal with an avocado correctly, here's a quick lesson:
To finish up your guacamole, mash your avocado up a bit and gently mix it into the magical citric-spice-tomato concoction. We're done here.
condiments.author: Ryan Sholin <ryansholin@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Grilled Pineapple Pear Salsa
ingredients: 1 large medium-firm pear sliced into 1/4 inch slices
1 large red bell pepper, seeded and quartered
1/2 small red onion, peeled and cut in half (so you have 2 quarters of a whole onion)
1/2 cup loosely packed cilantro, finely chopped
directions: Sautee red onions, pineapple, red bell peppers, pears, and jalapeno in olive oil on high heat. Do not move vegetables and pineapples around until they're slightly charred and caramelized.
Once the above ingredients are caramelized and charred, take them off the heat and place them in medium bowl.
Mix in cilantro, lime juice, ground ginger, ground cumin, and salt and pepper.
Can be eaten immediately but it is best served chilled.
condiments.author: Lulu <lilulu004@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Garlic Lime Sauce
condiments.description: This sauce packs a creamy, sour, garlicky punch and can cut the heat on a spicy salsa. It pairs well with Mango Lime Salsa for excellent fish tacos. This is a simplified version of the lime sauce recipe on Love and Oil.
directions: Whisk ingredients together in bowl.
Serve on the side, or drizzle as a decorative layer onto prepared tacos. Optionally sprinkle with chopped cilantro as garnish.
condiments.author: Javaun Moradi <jmoradi@npr.org>

condiments.title: European Sour Cream
condiments.description: It is hard to find sour cream in Europe. This is a suitable alternative using more readily available ingredients.
directions: Combine ingredients. Serve immediately or refrigerate.
condiments.author: yanofsky <github@yerit.com>

condiments.title: Creamy Mustard Sauce
condiments.description: Originally a sauce used on sandwiches until one day I ran out of sour cream for my tacos. This recipe is meant to be "eye-balled."
ingredients: 1/4 part Grey Poupon Harvest Course Ground Mustard
directions: Mix all ingredients in container.
Add to tacos, and anything else you'd like.
Store in closed container in fridge.
condiments.author: JimVanG <jjvg@me.com>

condiments.title: Cranberry Salsa
ingredients: 1 jalepeño, chopped small (remove seeds & wash for less heat)
directions: In a saucepan, get your water and sugar boiling, then add the cranberries. Boil until the cranberries pop (5-10 minutes), then take off heat, drain, and cool. They'll be slightly jelly-like, but you don't want them to disintegrate entirely, so watch them closely.
While the cranberries are cooling, chop your white onion, your jalepeño and cilantro.
Once your berries are cool, they'll probably have turned gooey. If there is still a bunch of water, drain it. But it's probably turned to jelly.

Combine everything, and give a good squeeze of lime over the whole thing. As you combine, you'll notice that the cranberries just give up their shape entirely. Also: Don't wear your finest clothing when you do this--this shit .

directions.title: Make adjustments based on taste here. Your main variables are:
directions: Sweet vs tangy. Default right now is tangy. Add more sugar for sweet.

Battling the overwhelmingness of the cranberries. You've got two things going with the cranberries here: flavor and texture. More onion will add more crunch to the whole thing, and help boost up the salsa-ness. Jalepeño is your heat adjustment--seeds are your friend. But the Cilantro is your big mover here: it helps to round out the sharpness of the cranberry. Lime also helps bring down the cranberry overload.

directions.title: Orange Cranberry Salsa Holographic Varient Cover:
directions: Go with half a cup of OJ and half a cup of water to boil your berries in.
Compliment the lime juice with a fresh squeezed orange and then  that motherfucker right into the salsa

condiments.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Chipotlé Sauce
ingredients: 2-3 chipotlé peppers, with surrounding adobo sauce from can
directions: Drop all of this into a food processor, and blend away.
Let sit in fridge for 30 minutes or overnight for flavor melding.
Add to tacos, and anything else you'd like.
condiments.author: katemyers <kate.myers@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Cilantro and Onion
condiments.description: Chop up some cilantro and onion (any variety) and put them on any taco.
condiments.author: Sean Fitzpatrick <sffitzpatrick@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Chipotle Pineapple Sauce
ingredients: 2-3 chipotle peppers, with surrounding adobo sauce from can
directions: Sautee the onion in the oil until translucent
Add pineapple and let cook for just a couple minutes
Add water and peppers and sauce and cook until reduced to just thinner than a paste
condiments.author: Aria Stewart <aredridel@dinhe.net>

condiments.title: Salsa de chile de árbol
condiments.description:
This is a go-to taco sauce in western Mexico and probably elsewhere. You can
mix and match the techniques in the two variants presented here, and substituting or adding chiles is a ramp onto the combinatorial superhighway of Mexican food and can demystify the salsa bar at the local taquería.
directions: Red
Green
condiments.author: Brian Mount <bvmount@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Charred Corn
ingredients: 6-8 ears of very fresh sweet corn.
Canola, peanut or other high-heat vegetable oil.
Sheet pan covered with tin foil.
directions: Prepare the oven for broiling by moving a single rack to the highest level. It should be no closer than 2-3 inches from the broiler.
Under this rack set the second rack and the sheet pan covered with tin foil to catch drips from the corn.
Brush each ear of corn lightly with oil.
Pull out top rack halfway and place the corn directly on the rack.
Push the rack in and turn on the broiler.
Watch the corn. You're looking for some fairly blackened bits and lots of dark brown.
Note: Do not let the corn catch on fire.
Turn the corn one quarter turn with the tongs. Repeat until each corn ear is fairly dark brown.
Remove the corn ears to the large metal bowl they are fully turned and browned/charred.
Turn off the broiler.
Let the corn cool for 15 minutes or until you can touch it.
Stand an ear of corn up on the bottom.
Using your sharpest knife, start at the top of the corn ear and slice down through the kernels. They will come off in sheets.
Turn the corn a quarter or a fifth turn and repeat until you've removed the kernels. Note: Some will stick at the top and bottom.
Do this for each ear of corn.
Now you have a bowl full of kernels. Mix with lime juice (2 limes?) and 3-6 oz of cotija to make a corn salad.
BONUS: Freeze the cobs. Later, make corn stock by boiling the cobs for an hour in 2 gallons of water. Remove the cobs and reduce to about 2 quarts. Use with grits or as a soup base.
condiments.author: jeremyjbowers <jeremyjbowers@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Cashew Cheeze
condiments.description: This is a good dairy sub but also just pretty damn delicious.
ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon salt (you can also play with other spices: garlic, cayenne, cumin etc. Go crazy!)
directions: In a large bowl add the raw cashews and hot water. Cover with a kitchen towel and allow to soak for 2-4 hours. Drain the cashews and rinse well.

Add the soaked cashews, salt, nutritional yeast, jalepeno and the lemon juice in a blender or food processor. Blend on high and stir frequently scraping down the sides of the bowl. Keep processing the mixture until it is very smooth, and there are no lumps.
Fold in the lemon zest (optional) and add to a serving bowl. You can also add a bit more water to get more of a creamy texture and store in a squeeze bottle (That's my preference anyway).
condiments.author: OpenShift guest <taryn.mazza@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Cabbage Slaw
ingredients: Sea salt and freshly ground black pepper
condiments.author: Erin Morrissey <erinmorrissey@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Caramelized Pineapple
condiments.description: If you're making crock pot al pastor, make this too.
ingredients: 1/3 of a pineapple, peeled and chopped in 1/2 inch dice
2 tablespoons reserved fat from   2 tablespoons neutral flavored oil such as canola, and 1/4 teaspoon chipotle powder.
directions: If not using the pork fat, toss the pineapple with the chipotle powder.
Heat the oil or fat in a pan over medium high heat. When it is hot, add the pineapple.
Don't stir too much, let it get good and brown, this takes a few minutes. Watch to make sure the pineappled doesn't burn. Stir once or twice to brown a few different sides of the fruit.
Serve warm.
condiments.author: bchartoff <bchartoff@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Black Olives
condiments.description: Canned black olives add a sweet and cool meatiness to a traditional American taco.
condiments.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

condiments.title: Beet Salsa
condiments.description: Tired of plain ol' Carne Asada Tacos? Get exotic with beet salsa.
ingredients: 10 garlic cloves (leave it up to your buds, I like 10 or more)
directions: Fry tomatoes, pepper(s), onion and garlic in a pan until they are brown and tomato skins are peeling away.
Move ingredients to the blender and purèe.
Chop beets to a blendable size and add to salsa.
Add salt and pepper to taste.
Squeeze in desired amount of lemon and blend one more time.
condiments.author: Shane Shifflett <shifflett.shane@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Avocado mango cilantro salsa
condiments.description: Recipe adapted from nom nom paleo.
ingredients: ½ cup finely diced red onion
directions: Combine ingredients in a bowl.
condiments.author: Madeleine Schönemann <madeleine.schonemann@tretton37.com>

condiments.title: Baja White Sauce
condiments.description: This is a traditional white sauce for Baja fish tacos.
ingredients: 1/4 tsp celery salt (or garlic salt, etc)
directions: Mix, and refrigerate for an hour if possible.
condiments.author: Kumar McMillan <kumar.mcmillan@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Asian Cabbage Slaw
condiments.description: Add this to Asian Style Tacos for a taste sensation.

ingredients.title: Dressing
ingredients: a squirt or two of sriracha

ingredients.title: Slaw
ingredients: some cilantro, chopped up, to taste

directions: Combine all the dressing ingredients in a big bowl, whirl them together until the sugar dissolves. Adjust the amount of sriracha in there to the heat you want your dressing to be.
Toss the chopped cabbage, onions, and cilantro in with the dressing.
Mix until everything is lightly dressed.
YAY EVERYTHING.
condiments.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Phoning it in Pico de Gallo
ingredients: 1 pint grape tomatoes, quartered (make your kids do this part)
As many finely chopped red (or green) jalapeños as you want (optional)
directions: Combine the tomatoes, cilantro and onion together in a bowl. Season to taste with salt and lime.
Reserve some of this mixture for kids, and then add as much jalapeño as you like to the remaining mixture for the non wimps.
condiments.author: littlewhirl <taryn.mazza@gmail.com>

condiments.title: Roasted Tomato Salsa
ingredients: 2 pounds roma tomatoes, cut in half lengthwise
1 large onion peeled, cut into slices
1 jalapeno pepper, halved (remove inside if you would like it less spicy)
Place tomatoes (skin side up), garlic, onion and jalapeno on cookie sheet and put in broiler for about 5 min. until skins start to blacken.
Remove from broiler and let cool (refrigerate to cool quicker or if you like warm salsa continue on to step 4.)
Place ALL ingredients into blender and blend until you have the consistancy you like.
condiments.author: CJ R <cj@null.computer>

mixins.title: Veggies for Fish Tacos
mixins.description: Fish tacos are a special breed, requiring different vegetable options.
ingredients: Cherry tomatoes, sliced (if you're a heathen)
Cilantro, if it doesn't taste like soap to you
Limes, sliced for juicing over tacos.
directions: Place out your selections and assemble into your taco. Then squeeze a lime over the top.
mixins.author: katemyers <kate.myers@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Traditional Taco Mixins
directions: Add ingredients to tacos in layers.
mixins.author: Katherine Michel <kthrnmichel@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Tomatoes (Traditional; US)
mixins.description: Adding a bit of coolness and moisture, tomatoes are a staple ingredient of the American taco. The better the tomato the more flavor they will impart, but even a sub-standard grocery store tomato has a place in a traditional taco.
mixins.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

mixins.title: Sweet Potato and Apple Hash
mixins.description: Sweet potatoes are my go-to taco punch-up. I was going my normal route of making small (1/4" or so) cubes of sweet potatoes when I thought: Hey, it's fall, I'm going to add an apple in there. Fuck yes.
ingredients: 2 Small sweet potatoes (you'd be amazed how little sweet potato you need for tacos)
A couple pinches of chili powder
directions: Mix this all into a pan, with about 1/4 cup of water, and boil it all up until the water goes away, toss in the butter, and continue to pan-fry until things get a little browned.
mixins.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Pomegranate Seeds
mixins.description:
Technically called arils, pomegranate seeds are tasty little things. They pack a powerfully tart punch, and add some crunch to a taco that might need some textural assistance.

You want a pomegranate that feels heavy for its size and has a firm, tight skin. (Weight and firmness are indicators of how much juice is inside.)

Here are two methods for getting the seeds out of the membrane.
directions: The Water Method
The Wooden Spoon Method
mixins.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

mixins.title: Fajita-style peppers, onions, and mushrooms
mixins.description: Sauteed veggies that go great with almost any base layer.
directions: Dice onions, peppers, and mushrooms
Heat oil in skillet
Sautee onion until soft
Add bell peppers; cook several minutes on medium heat
Add mushrooms; cook until liquid is almost gone, stirring regularly
Season to taste with spices
mixins.author: reddigari <samirreddigari@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Sauted Shitake Mushroom and Wasabi Salad
ingredients: Wasabi-covered sesame seeds (available at the local Asian mart. If you can't find it, sub just a smidge of wasabi)
directions: Place shitakes in a bowl and cover with warm water. Soak for about 20 minutes or until shitakes are completely rehydrated. Remove mushrooms and squeeze excess water from them. They don't need to be completely dry, but shouldn't be sopping wet.

Heat olive oil over medium-high heat in a small frying pan. Throw in soy sauce and red wine vinegar. How much depends on your taste. I would start with a tablespoon of each and adjust from there. I like the salad to be a bit more acidic so I tend to add a splash more of the red wine vinegar. Sauté mushrooms for a couple of minutes until they are heated through. Season to taste with salt. Adjust soy sauce and red wine vinegar as needed. Before serving, sprinkle a little bit of the wasabi-covered sesame seeds over the mushrooms to impart a little color, crunchiness, and heat. If you are unable to find wasabi-covered sesame seeds, a dab of wasabi and sprinkle of plain sesame seeds should do the trick.
notes: I keep dried shitakes as a staple in my pantry. I love the fact that the water left over after you rehydrate the mushrooms is called mushroom liquor. Mushroom liquor can be used as a substitute for broth or water in many recipes to impart an lovely mushroomy flavor.
mixins.author: nowowl <c.d.lee82@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Lettuce (Traditional; US)
mixins.description: In a traditional American taco, lettuce serves to add extra crunch and coolness. Favor the bulkier lettuces over leafier fare such as Bibb lettuces or mesclun.
mixins.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

mixins.title: Green Chile Cabbage Salad with Seared Corn
mixins.description: This isn't a tradition, or even particularly traditional -- except in my apartment in Oakland, where I make this for myself ever time I make pork tacos.
ingredients: 2 ears corn, or roughly two cups of corn kernels (adjust to desired corn-y-ness)
Dried, Powdered New Mexico Green Chile, to taste
Optional: some crumbled cotija or queso Oaxaqueno
directions: If using ears of corn, strip the kernels from them with a sharp knife.
Heat a few tablespoons of oil over high heat. I like to use a Dutch Oven for this, but the main cookware properties you want are heavy-bottomed and wide.

Toss the corn kernels in to the oil, spread them evenly, salt very lightly and let them ride. I  recommend a splatter guard for this step, but  a lid. You want the corn to dry out just a little and get a good sear. It's done when it's starting to get dark, a little chewy, and probably is sticking to the pan.
While the corn is going, core and chop the cabbage in to wide strips.
How's the corn doing?
Juice the limes.
How's the corn doing? If it's not done yet, grab a beer and hang out 'til it is.

The corn is done? Great. Toss it on top of the cabbage. Add a little salt, then a good hit of olive oil, then half-or-so of the lime juice. Toss in a good tablespoon or two of the green chile powder. Start stirring.

You want everything coated nicely, but I don't like the salad too oily, so go easy on that. I add lime until the sour balances the sweet of the corn. I add green chile slowly -- it takes a second to rehydrate and get hot. I might add as much as a half cup of the stuff to a salad for myself or spicy food fans like me; I go easier on the spice-unenthused.

Serve it! If you're in to tossing a little cheese on there, do it -- but I usually just eat it straight. Sometimes this goes on fish or chicken tacos; sometimes it's a side to richer pork tacos. It's always awesome.
notes: green chile is the gastronomical life blood of New Mexican cuisine, but it's little known in the other 49 states. I like a brand called , which I can find sometimes in tiendas and other times at Whole Foods (go figure). The trick here is this: just don't accept substitutes. It's not the same. I've also had to accept that fresh chile is just not what this salad needs, so don't do that either (it doesn't distribute well enough across the cabbage). Do have this with cold, crisp beer.
mixins.author: Ross Donaldson <gastove@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Drunken Green Beans
mixins.description: Green beans are fine. Green beans cooked in beer are better. Maybe even the best.
ingredients: 1 Surly fist full of green beans
directions: First peel and dice the garlic and sauté it in the olive oil. Before it gets all burned and ruined, add the beer and vegetable broth.

As the liquid comes to a boil, cut the green beans up. Add the green beans and a pinch of salt and let them simmer for about five minutes. If you like your beans on the softer side you can let it go a little longer. But the trick is to pull them right after the color starts to turn and you've just made a delicious addition to any taco.
mixins.author: Jesse von Doom <jesse@cashmusic.org>

mixins.title: Cheese (Traditional; US)
mixins.description: A major flavor component of a traditional American taco, select a cheese that's firm and sharp.
mixins.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

mixins.title: Shredded Brussels Sprouts
mixins.description:
A surprising, unexpected and delicious green addition to your taco!

You're not going to LOAD UP your taco with these, but they bring an amazing, mellow flavor to the mix. Especially good with fish tacos.
directions: Shred up your brussels sprouts so that they're flaked up. You're really going for almost a slaw-level shredding here.
Put a healthy amount of butter in a pan, melt it down with a little salt too.
Toss the shredded sprouts in, and fry 'em up until parts of them are browned up, and other parts have turned into a bright green. You're going for partial caramelization, but not all the way.
mixins.author: sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Potato Hash
ingredients: 6 or so small yukon gold potatoes
directions: Peel and dice potatoes, throw in a pan with a 1/4 or so of water, cover and cook on medium-high until potatoes are soft.
Once potatoes are soft, lower to medium heat add green onions, chiles, spices and olive oil. Cook until hash-like. BOOM.
mixins.author: OpenShift guest <taryn.mazza@gmail.com>

mixins.title: Corn Salad
ingredients: Garlic salt, or Garlic AND salt. I use Trader Joe's Garlic Salt in the grinder usually.
directions: Cut the corn off of the cob, and in a mixing bowl mix together corn, lime juice, chopped cilantro and garlic salt. You can tweak any of this stuff as desired.
notes: This is my first Github commit. I'm glad it's taco related.
mixins.author: OpenShift guest <taryn.mazza@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Sriracha Salt
seasonings.description:
I actually received this as a gift, but I found a recipe to make your own.

The effect on most food is as awesome as you'd expect but it is especially amazing with eggs. Add it to your breakfast tacos.
directions: Mix the two ingredients together in a bowl.
Spread it out on a baking sheet lined with foil or parchment paper.
Put in a 200-degree oven, then turn the oven off and let it sit overnight inside. It will clump, but place in ziplock bag and attack it with a rolling pin. Tada!
seasonings.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Sriracha Marinade
seasonings.description: Alone on a Saturday night, I put on Iron Maiden, cubed up a pork chop and whipped this marinade together:
ingredients: tsp or so of ground ancho chile
directions: Get this coated nicely over everything before frying or grilling on high heat.
seasonings.author: sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Quick and Dirty Spice Mix
seasonings.description: I’m not going to make a lot of big assumptions here. You own a skillet of some sort. You have some jars of jankity-ass spices from who-knows-when. You want to eat some tacos within the next, like, fifteen minutes. I got you covered, bachelor(ette).
ingredients: 3/4 tsp. onion powder (or 1 1/2 tsp. minced yellow onion)
directions: Put all this in something with a lid, add 3/4 cup of water, and shake it. Brown a pound of ground beef, then pour the whole situation in there. Stir. Cook it down until it looks like you only put in half a cup of water. You have tacos now.
notes: I’ve made this with that soy protein “ground beef” and it does not  taste like someone put spices on a stack of cheap bar coasters and ran it all through a blender. (Vegetable) oil the skillet when you’re dealing with that stuff, unless you’re looking for excuses to buy a new one.
If you leave out the bouillon for the sake of doing things vegan-style you’ll probably want to nudge up the salt a little.
seasonings.author: Mat Marquis <mat@matmarquis.com>

seasonings.title: Packaged Seasonings
seasonings.description:
Lest we be accused of snobbery, let's acknowledge that a taco is a taco, and taco night can be well-served by not having to think at all.

Feel free to use the pre-packaged seasoning of your choice. When I'm in an old-school mood, I head straight for...
seasonings.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim@monkeydo.biz>

seasonings.title: Mahi Mahi Rub
seasonings.description: A rub for Mahi Mahi, if fish tacos be what you're fancying. You choose your measurements and enjoy!
seasonings.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Homemade Sriracha
seasonings.description:
Sure, Huy Fong's “rooster” brand sriracha is great, but wouldn't be nice to make your own? Now you can.

A few tips before starting:


Don't be a cowboy (or cowgirl)-use gloves. You are going to be handling a lot of peppers and the last thing you want to do is touch your eye or a more sensitive body part.
Have good ventilation. Especially on the day you bring your chilis to a boil.
ingredients: 1 pound red jalepeño pepper, stemmed, seeded and halved.
½ pound red serrano  pepper, stemmed, seeded and halved.
¼ pound red thai chiles, stemmed, and halved.
4 tablespoons palm sugar (light brown sugar can be substituted, see notes).
½ cup cane vinegar (or rice wine vinegar, ).
directions: Combine chilis, garlic, salt and sugar in food processor. Pulse to a coarse pureé.
Transfer pureé to glass container. Store at room temperature for one week, stirring daily (see notes).
After one week, transfer pureé to small saucepan, add vinegar and bring to boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for five minutes. Allow to cool to room temperature.
Transfer pureé to food processor and process for two to three minutes.
Strain pureé through fine mesh strainer, using back of spoon or rubber spatula to press solids through strainer.
Transfer finished sauce to glass jars and refrigerate. Can be stored for up to 6 months.
notes: Any combination of red chile peppers will make a fine sriracha. Note thai chilis and serrano are hotter than jalepeños, so experiment with different combinations and find one that works for your taste.

If you can't find palm sugar (usually found in most Asian markets) light brown sugar can be substituted. Light brown sugar is slightly sweeter so you may want to start with three tablespoons and adjust after tasting before step 3.

Likewise, if you cannot find cane vinegar, rice wine vinegar can be substituted. Seasoned rice wine vinegar, commonly used in preparing sushi rice often has been sweetened, so keep that in mind if adjusting sweetener.
Some recipes have suggested the pureé can be thick after the seven day fermentation and water can be used to thin the mixture when processing after the boiling/simmering stage.

Finally, and  be sure to santize the glass jars/containers you use to ferment and store your sriracha. Just ask your favorite homebrewer what can happen if you do not properly sanitize your glass container before storing foodstuffs in them.
seasonings.author: Michael Bishop <miklb@miklb.com>

seasonings.title: Chipotle Rub
seasonings.description: Great rub/spice mix for shrimp, beef or pork.
directions: Stir to combine and apply to your protein of choice.
seasonings.author: Erin Morrissey <erinmorrissey@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Basic Dry Rub
seasonings.description: This is a great, versatile recipe to use as a taco seasoning or as a dry rub for the protein of your choice. Equally at home in the skillet, oven, stovetop, or smoker.
directions: Stir to combine and apply liberally.
seasonings.author: pmcg <patrickmcghen@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Zaatar
seasonings.description:
A.k.a. za‘tar, za’atar, zattr, etc.

Zaatar is a thyme-based Middle Eastern seasoning that adapts well to tacos. It has a pleasantly dry, faintly sour/bitter flavor. It goes well on savory bases like squash and lamb, and combines with other sour seasonings like lemon juice and radish.

There are many kinds of zaatar, some quite different; this recipe is representative, not definitive.
ingredients: 1 unit sumac (to be found at a Lebanese or Syrian market, or at a yuppie grocery; in a pinch, lemon zest can substitute)
Other herbs to taste: fennel pollen, marjoram, cumin, etc.
Optional: trace olive oil or lemon juice as a binder (but not if you plan to store it)
directions: Toast the sesame seeds. Grind all ingredients together using any method, stopping when the mixture is not too fine to pick up by pinching.
May be added to meat during cooking, or sprinkled over a finished taco.
The latest theories have not ruled out the possibility of a zaatar mole.
seasonings.author: Charlie Loyd <celoyd@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Universal Taco Seasoning
seasonings.description: I got tired of buying packets of store-bought taco seasoning, so I experimented with various spices and ratios until I landed on this recipe. I keep a jar of it in the cupboard at all times.
ingredients: 4 tsp oregano (Mexican oregano, if you've got it)
directions: Combine in Mason jar and shake well to combine.
notes: This mix works well for chicken, pork and beef, destined for the grill, oven, slow cooker or stovetop. You could tweak it a bit to target a specific meat, but I like to have a base, universal mix around. Makes it super easy to turn leftover anything into delicious taco filling: Just chop up whatever it is, toss it into a skillet, sprinkle generously with seasoning, then add a bit of water and simmer to impart flavor.
seasonings.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

seasonings.title: Kathy's Taco and Fajita Seasoning
seasonings.description:
My cousin Kathy sent me this recipe for my birthday:

Amazing taco/fajita seasoning – Use with any protein.  It's a great recipe to quadruple so you have it ready for immediate taco needs. When making a big batch, use less salt.
ingredients: 1 tsp EACH: paprika, onion powder, dried oregano, and kosher salt
½ tsp EACH: ground coriander, garlic powder and black pepper
¼ tsp EACH: red pepper flakes, ground ginger and cayenne pepper
seasonings.author: Daniel Sinker <dansinker@gmail.com>

shells.title: Perfect Flour Tortillas
shells.description:
This recipe is courtesy of Cynthia Detterick-Pineda at Whats Cooking America.

Yields: Approximate 15 tortillas
Prep time: 15 min
ingredients: 4 to 6 tablespoons lard or vegetable shortening
directions: If you follow the instructions provided, your tortillas will turn out perfectly - hence the name.
Make sure to follow the handling methods and resting times closely. They can make or break the texture.
shells.author: Shane Wright <kcshane@gmail.com>

shells.title: naan
shells.description:
Naan bread can be purchased or made. It is easier to buy it at a store.

Naan bread is a flatbread that tends to be fluffy and easy to tear apart.
shells.author: nick11robers <nick.roberts.127.0.0.1@gmail.com>

shells.title: Low Carb Tacos
shells.description:
For those who are on an Atkins or Low carb diet this is a recipe I found on you tube for a low carb taco shells using cheese.


Use real cheese instead of the processed stuff.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6n019s5SCi4
directions: Take a round-sliced piece of provolone and place it on a plate.
Microwave for 15-30 seconds
Fold/form into a taco shape by hand.
shells.author: Mosab Sasi <smosab@gmail.com>

shells.title: bad-ass tortillas
shells.description: If you are making tacos, don't settle for corporate store bought tortillas. Make your own like a real person!
directions: First get a cast iron pan:
Then one of these bad-ass tortilla presses:
Buy your lard from a place like this:
Mix all ingredients together except oil and water. Drizzle oil over mixture and mix with hands. Add water and mix and knead again until doughy. Let chill for about an hour in plastic wrappers.

Heat large cast iron skillet (or something more authentic if you've got it) over medium heat. Cut dough into about 12 pieces that are round. Use a proper tortilla press (or something more authentic if you've got it) to make 'em flat and then put on the skillet. Wait until the transparent parts turn opaque and flip em. Put cooked tortillas in a  cloth napkin to keep 'em warm. End recipe. Paz, amor, y dinero.
shells.author: Jeff Larson <thejefflarson@gmail.com>

shells.title: Hard Corn Shells (Traditional; US)
shells.description:
Mistakenly thought by many to be traditionally Mexican, hard shells were actually popularized in the US in the mid-20th century.

While they can certainly be made at home (if you have access to a deep-fryer), the best method of obtaining hard taco shells is to head to the grocery store.

If you line them with a lettuce leaf rather than using chopped lettuce, when the shell cracks you won't lose the contents into your lap.
shells.author: Tim Murtaugh <tim.murtaugh@ogilvy.com>

shells.title: Fresh Corn Tortillas
shells.description: This is the only way to go. So worth it. Makes roughly 15 tortillas.
directions: In a medium bowl, mix together masa harina and hot water until thoroughly combined. Turn dough onto a clean surface and knead until pliable and smooth. If dough is too sticky, add more masa harina; if it begins to dry out, sprinkle with water. Cover dough tightly with plastic wrap and allow to stand for 30 minutes.
Preheat a cast iron skillet or griddle to medium-high.

Divide dough into 15 equal-size balls. Using a tortilla press (or a rolling pin), press each ball of dough flat between two sheets of wax paper (plastic wrap or a freezer bag cut into halves will also work).

Place tortilla in preheated pan and allow to cook for approximately 30 seconds, or until browned and slightly puffy. Turn tortilla over to brown on second side for approximately 30 seconds more, then transfer to a plate. Repeat process with each ball of dough. Keep tortillas covered with a towel to stay warm and moist (or a low temp oven) until ready to serve.
shells.author: OpenShift guest <taryn.mazza@gmail.com>
